page.title: 02Wildlife on the South Downs
page.content:
The South Downs is filled with unusual wildlife. The Downs are made of Chalk which provides a good home for rabbits and small rodents, such as mice.
The insects found on the Downs reflect the richness of plant life. The two commonest butterflies are the Small Heath and Common Blue,although their numbers have been declining in recent years. Grasshoppers are abundant,the most common being the Striped _ Winged Grasshopper.
In the air blackbirds,wrens, yellowhammers,chaffinches and robins are common. Cuckoos are also common and skylarks are typical downland birds. The only bird of prey seen frequently is the kestrel.
